Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Decoding and Predicting Greenland's Surface Melt History and Future with Observations, Regional Atmospheric Modeling, and GCMs
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators plan a three-year effort to improve understanding and prediction of surface melting on the Greenland ice sheet. Satellite remote-sensing, regional climate modeling and nonlinear analysis techniques will be used to: assess variability of observed surface melt occurrence; benchmark model-based melt proxies versus observed melt; diagnose synoptic-scale meteorological/sea-ice controls on melt; and assess future change in melt proxies based on regional models driven by CMIP5 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5) general circulation models (GCMs). Understanding surface melt on polar ice sheets is important because surface melt affects albedo, can produce useful paleoclimatic records, contributes to mass balance through runoff, and is a trigger for ice-shelf collapse leading to ice-flow acceleration and sea-level rise. Improved understanding of the synoptic-meteorological causes of melting, and of the ability of state-of-the-art models to simulate melting accurately, would help assess the effects of future warming on melting, ice-sheet flow and sea level rise. The investigators propose three main research themes to help address these issues: (1) regional-atmospheric-model skill assessments and diagnosis of present synoptic controls on surface melt; (2) application of results from the model skill assessments to GCM-based climate scenarios for estimates of future change; and (3) expanding satellite-based retrieval of surface melt state characterization through retrieval of melt magnitude using a novel fusion of passive microwave and optical/thermal satellite data. In addition to addressing key questions relating Greenland ice sheet balance to sea-level change, the project includes outreach to the public, primarily through a web site, and numerous educational impacts. The project would support undergraduate and graduate students, and involves investigators from a primarily undergraduate institution with a significant population of first-generation college students, and from a Hispanic-serving institution. All data and model results will be archived and made available through the ACADIS data center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historic and recent assessments of surface melting have been restricted to determination of the extent and duration of melting over both Antarctica and Greenland.  Though these efforts have been insightful, they only record the presence of melt and not the magnitude. Characterization of melt is a complicated phenomenon as the approach for detection dictates the mode of melt states that can be measured and quantified. Passive microwave system are able to detect melt over a larger effect depth (~1 m), where during melt, the effective emission depth can vary by a few centimeters, with the assumption that the active layers contributing to upwelling emission are at or close to 0 °C. This results in greater sensitivity to melt/refreeze conditions. Measured radiances in the optical and thermal parts of the EM spectrum are largely sensitive to grain metamorphism driven by melt as well as changes in the thermal state of the firn due to heat fluxes from the atmosphere. Assessment of melt in the optical/thermal parts of the EM spectrum is limited to the upper few centimeters. Passive microwave approaches have evolved, primarily based on the effective difference in firn emissivity as a function of increased absorption due to the presence of liquid water particularly in the 19-37 GHz range.

A new approach has been developed to retrieve melt magnitude or liquid water fraction (LWF) using coupled optical and thermal signatures derived from an optical thermal spectroradiometer.

With the increase in duration and extent of surface melt over the Greenland Ice Sheet, an assessment of the magnitude of melt is paramount. Given this we sought to address the following:

  • How wide spread has the occurrence of surface melt been in accumulation zone of the ice sheet?
  • What is the magnitude of melt in the interior of the ice sheet associated with documented anomalous warm periods over the last decade?
  • What is the temporal variability in melt onset, duration, and magnitude in the interior of the ice sheet?

We seek to answer these question through the application of the melt magnitude retrieval scheme which assess the amount of surface liquid water fraction (eq. 1) over the Greenland Ice Sheet at elevations > 2500 meters over the analysis period from 2009 to 2017. We examine estimates of retrieved surface liquid fraction over the melt season (late May to l) in 8-day composted intervals over the analysis period. This analysis interval is an extension of previous work in the retrieval of surface liquid water fraction using MODIS imagery from 2000 to 2008.

 

Most seasons approach upwards of 0.6% for a maximum. As the season advanced most years show an increase in the variability in LWFeff. Some seasons show substantial variation throughout the melt season such as 2010 and 2012.

 

The GrIS has experienced significant and wide spread warming over the last couple decades resulting in increasing occurrence and intensity of surface melting over the accumulation and percolation zones. In this effort, we specifically focus on a decomposition of melt magniude over the accumulation zone of the ice sheet. Overall conditions in the accumulation zone of the ice sheet experience very low melt magnitudes and do not exceed melt amounts sufficient for passive microwave sensors to register melting except for select years such as 2012. The 2012 season was documented as an anomalous year for ice sheet-wide melt occurrence. Even though the magnitude are low, this analysis offers insights into evolving conditions across the accumulation zone which has implications for firn evolution. Much of this information would be useful in calibrating/validating firn evolution models and support constraining mass balance. As a diagnostic tool, this work provides a novel way to enhance our assessment of surface melting beyond a binary classification and reveals the complex spatial and temporal conditions experienced across the ice sheet during the melt season.
